messages.messageBody:
Milt,
I'm going to spend more time thinking about my next wish, then.

Good call. The decoration does look like Hizen work, which is unusual for the Iyo Shoami. Is there by a personal name on the other side? I wonder if the maker worked in Kyushu previously or was just copying the style. The Iyo Shoami generally did not go in for that much nunome decoration. The rim treatment kind of looks like the late Jingo/Kumagai work. The man was a Kyushu stylist serving the greater Shikoku market I suppose.

BTW, the use of that character for shu in Yoshu (Iyo) is something that the Iyo Shoami tended to do.

Jim

Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: maandag 19 januari 2004 21:20
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Nanban Tsuba


Matt,
The variety of terms used to describe tsuba decorated in foreign style
can be confusing (Nanban, Canton, Kagonami, etc.). Of course Hizen, and
Nagasaki in particular, was the major point of contact with foreigners
and their goods. Guards made in Europe or China would have been seen
first in Hizen. A lot of the foreign-influenced styles of "nanban
tsuba" were probably initially made in Hizen. The "dragon and vines"
type is so numerous that it was probably mass produced in other parts of
Japan.

I'm sure that you can find exceptions in the usage, but most of the time
the term Hizen is used for solid plate, iron guards with profuse, showy
silver or multi-color nunome. The motifs are often foreign-influenced,
the plates are sometimes cupped like European guards, and they do share
some decorative traits with the "dragon and vines" type like dragon
motifs and a rectangular seppa dai (although in the case of the Hizen
tsuba, it's usually just outlined with nunome). I don't think I've ever
seen the dragon and vines type called Hizen.

There seems to be some consensus that the earliest nanban tsuba from the
late 16th to early 17th C were made outside of Japan. I think that is
what Graham is talking about and they are rather rare. The huge
majority of pieces that we see in "dragon in vines" style are later and
made in Japan.

Foreign influence found its way into arts beyond tsuba. There were
various nanban-style wares made in Japan, lacquer chests and furnishings
(even nanban saya), clothing, painting, etc. The nanban items made in
Japan must far outnumber the imported ones that inspired them.

Jim



Gang, going off topic a little, but still on the Graham Gemmel Book,
at
one point he discusses a nanban type tsuba with the very busy 'dragon
in
vines' type of decoration that is associated with 'Canton' style.

He reckons that these tsuba were actually made in China and India,
where
they were ordered by the Dutch who then sold them in Japan!

He goes on to say that alot of these tsuba were actually made
somewhere
other than Japan, and they are quite different to Nanban tsuba, which
simply means in 'foreign taste' or done in 'foreign metal' etc etc.

And while we are on the subject, what is the difference between Hizen
and Nanban tsuba? They must have alot in common simply because they
were
probably made in more or less the same place I assume?

Matt

messages.msgSnippet: ... Yeeeeess...  but...  I have heard it said that a samurai who assiduously practised his swordsmanship @ 5,000 draws a day (or more) would wear out a saya in
messages.messageBody:
Trickie Turner wrote:

> but I wonder. would the abrasiveness not "file down" the
> wood of the saya over time, and probably faster that usual ?.

Yeeeeess... but... I have heard it said that a samurai who assiduously
practised his swordsmanship @ 5,000 draws a day (or more) would wear out a saya
in 6 months!! So, who gives a stuff about wear at the scabbard mouth!! I know
from talking with a Japanese collector that saya - even nicely lacquered ones -
were considered expendable items in the days of the samurai. If you were
somewhat hard up, it would always be possible to glue a shaving of wood into the
scabbard mouth to re-tighten the habaki fit.

Barry Thomas.

From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, January 16, 2004 9:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Cat scratches - yasurimei on habaki


Matt,
Yujo refers to Goto Yujo, the first generation. I hadn't noticed the term Yujo yasuri before, although as I mentioned in an earlier post he does seem to be the first one applying fine sujigai yasuri to gold kogai, at least as far as surviving and published examples go.

Checking Kajihara's glossary again, the terms Yujo-yasuri habaki and koshi-Yujo habaki are listed in the habaki section on page 146. There is no drawing for a Yujo-yasuri habaki, just some text. There is a drawing of a koshi-Yujo habaki, which looks like the ones you pointed out. Both sources are saying that the fine filework on the lower half are the Yujo-yasuri. I think that the work on the upper part is what is usually referred to as cat scratch. Although Kajihara describes the term nekogaki, he doesn't provide an illustration.

I have never seen file work by Yujo or other Goto makers that had the raised and burnished burs that appear on these habaki. Their file marks are fine and smooth. Probably a somewhat different tool and/or technique. This work with the raised bumps is quite typical of habaki, but I have seen it on the backs of some machibori kodogu.

Oddly the text in Kajihara about Yujo yasuri habaki does not appear in the English translation volume. It says something like that this is a kind of ji-yasuri habaki that is called Yujo-yasuri because it is like the style of yasuri particular to Yujo. The koshi-Yujo habaki is based on this.

If someone knows more about this or other habaki lore, please let us know.

Jim



Ok guys, check this out: http://www.ksky.ne.jp/~sumie99/habaki.html

look at the third type of habaki, a gold and silver one are illustrated
called 'koshi-Yujo'.

Who was Yujo and is this a type of 'cat scratch' habaki?

- Matt

messages.msgSnippet: ... Well, not so much lore, but just another thought .  One of the great things I have admired in Nihonto is that even the apparently decorative always has a
messages.messageBody:
Jim Gilbert wrote:

> If someone knows more about this or other habaki lore, please let us know.

Well, not so much lore, but "just another thought". One of the great things I
have admired in Nihonto is that even the apparently decorative always has a
practical purpose. The taper on a habaki performs the same function in the saya
as does the taper on a car's rear axle and hub. It "locks", requiring some
force to break the "union" of the two parts. The "cat scratches/rain" roughen
the surface which would allow more "bite" - hence locking force - of a habaki in
the saya mouth.

How many of you have seen a still well-fitting habaki in an antique koshirae
where the sword can be held upside down and vigouously shaken without the blade
falling out?? Magnificent work of the artisans.

Barry Thomas.
